instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2838: What is 820-2838? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A overheat
threads.message:
Anyone think of a way the dc in board can be bad and
cause the cpu to overheat?, usually boot up one time
then freeze up and not work again till it sits and cools.
Either that or I am very unlucky with boards as I have
had 3 do the exact same thing...

This one is pulling 1 amp through the power supply and
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is down to .98v which seems would
be the result if there is a short pulling a lot of current.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A overheat
threads.message: It’s overheating because it’s old...but inspect for corrosion near the SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A overheat
threads.message:
These are 'good tested board' from different sellers, Just wanted to make
sure it couldn't be something else other then the logic board. I guess need to
just part out all the good parts and not try to find working logic board.
